header.title: Woman ‘calls train passenger foreign b*****d’ for sitting in her seat
header.postText: A woman has been filmed carrying out a racist rant at a fellow passenger on a train filled with protesters on their way home from an anti-racism march.', 'Passengers said they intervened as the woman aggressively complained someone had sat in her seat, demanding to see her train ticket, telling her to ‘f*** off’ and repeatedly calling her a ‘foreign b***ard’.', 'Witnesses offered solidarity to the victim, an Asian woman, by telling the white aggressor ‘we are foreign too’.', 'The incident took place on the 8.25pm train from London Euston to Birmingham New Street on Saturday as many passengers were returning from a UN Anti-Racism Day rally in the capital.', 'The person filming it said: ‘I was utterly disgusted by the behaviour of this racist train passenger, and the racially abusive things she said to other passengers.', '‘As some form of bizarre defence, she even claimed she was “foreign” herself, which her friend later confirmed as untrue.', '‘Regardless, her behaviour was abhorrent and her views wholly inappropriate, more so as it was international anti-racism day, and only a day after a racist terrorist massacre in New Zealand where similar views led to the murder of 50 innocent Muslims.’', 'Witnesses said the Asian passenger eventually gave up her seat but the confrontation continued.', 'It has been claimed the abusive woman mocked her accent during the stand-off, then again in conversation with her friends.', 'Passengers who saw the incident claim the white woman said: ‘If she gets off at Coventry, I’ll kill her.’', 'She and other people travelling with her eventually got off the train at Coventry station.', 'The London rally marking the UN International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination saw more than 10,000 people march from Park Lane to Whitehall, stopping to pay their respects along the way at New Zealand House embassy.
header.socioLingVar: Ethnicity - General,Gender - General,Age - Youngsters,Nationality - General,Age - Over 65s,Ethnicity - Black

replies.commentText: To be fair she doesnt need to be a racist bigot just because somebody is sitting in her seat. There is NEVER any justification for racism. Nice try though.
Tamsyn Bouttell She called the person forgien, that's not racism.

Nicola Warner; mocking someone’s accent is though. Why are you trying to split hairs with semantics? She’s clearly racist.

Tamsyn Bouttell Xenophobic? Yes I 100% agree. Racist? No because the race of the person was not brought into question.Are they similar? Yes. Are they the same? Not at all.

Mariya Mahmood Well no, the deiniftion of the word is vastly important when calling someone out on being racist. It has a VERY specific meaning and it's not a blanket term to be used lightly.The comments made by the "attacker" did not mention race, so how can it be a rasict attack? Xenophobic is the correct word to use as it was an "attack" based on the person in question being a foreigner (whether true or not is rrelevenat, that's what the attcker based the comments on, no t race). Again, not once w as race broguht up. Ergo, not racist.

Steve, although I agree xenophobic would be a better word to use, often ' racist' and ' 'xenophobe' are used interchangeably it's not always easy to be so politically correct. After all all this is the metro and FB! My point is the attack was still insenisitive and completely our of order ans that should be the focus. even calling one 'foreign' based solely on their appearance is due to racial reading. You could be a Person of colour but born in the UK that doesn't make you foreign. It makes you just as much of a British national as my English neighbour. I understand where you're coming from, but racist or not her behaviour was uncalled for.

replies.commentText: Nicola Warner sorry.. other round racism? Huh? That does not exist. And the divide is created by people who act like that gal.

Montse Pearce I'm afraid to tell you it does exist, I was racially abused all through my growing up for being white and growing up in a multi culture area, I saw friends of mine badly beaten for being "white crackers" and unable to retaliate. I've Also seen Terrible racism between other races such as somalians and Jamaicans, its the just a white problem I don't agree with this woman at all but it's not a one way street. Middle classes seem to be totally unaware of this and stick their head in the sand thus being just as much a part of the problem.
No one should be threatened because the colour of their skin white or black, history doesn't justify It. Equality is equality not tit for tat, not a pendulum of fairness

Nicola Warner, don't compare your experience to that of the Afro-Caribbean or south Asian community. Our parents suffered blatant and abhorrent racial discrimination. Denied jobs and housing, simply due to skin colour.Numerous surveys have shown discrimination in the job market still exists, particularly towards south Asian and Muslim employees.There has been a long and tragic list of racist murders. And such hostility is thriving today. You've absolutely no idea what racism is.

I’m white British and been called horrible names but I only suffered from racism off this one lady, there’s no need for it, I can understand why people get so upset I even hate watching movies involving that subject and slavery, I feel like we going back in time, it’s ridiculous, no one can help what colour they born and there’s good and bad in all, that idiot on the train just proved that

Nicola Warner On a train from Cardiff to London I witnessed a similar event .An old Jewish gentleman returning to his booked seat after a toilet break found ensconced in his reserved seat an individual ( who we latter found was Bangladeshi).He politely asked the individual to vacate his seat only to be meet with a torrent of foul language and racial abuse.When surrounding passenger's intervened the Jewish gentleman being well into his 70s and the Individual having become quite physical.A number of people phoned forward to Paddington to have the train meet by police. On arriving the police were there but were unwilling to charge the individual with inciting racial Hatred.
